subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Update on intelligent Senior QS Font.
msgSnippet: Here s some observations , maybe even a critique. First, Fontographer is a great program and you won t regret purchasing it! May it produce many happy new
messageBody:
[Read_Alphabet] Re: Update on intelligent Senior QS Fo
Here's some "observations", maybe even a "critique."

First, Fontographer is a great program and you won't regret purchasing it! May it produce many happy new fonts for all of us.

QS2 reads well on the screen, with much more body than the original Jerome.  But I used it in printing out an 800 word text in 12 pt on an inkjet printer (certainly not small!) and certain kerning issues were quickly visible.
It was most apparent with "i" and "t". as in these words  bigiGN  lq^ul[i   eèistN.  Again, you'll have to print them out to really see what I mean.

I notice than you chose not to carry the characters far below the baseline.  This is fine, but it has created a very small negative space in "m", and "@"  so small, in fact, that it is almost not there. Likewise Notice printing @an. or ~It.    Here too the first letters would benefit from kerning so that it rises to meet the next letter

In addition to the disappearing  open space of "m", there is the issue of connections.  If the end of that character was raised above the base line, then not only would the open space be greater (without any more descent), but it would have a visible connection to letters that start above the base line like A. The same could be said of your  b.

I must say I don't take to your "u" shape. The sound Ado has two glyphs, "a" and "u".  The former starts at the bottom left and ends upper right, and the latter should start upper left and end lower right.  This gives the maximum connecting points possible to this very common sound.  Your "u" starts so far right that it almost looked like a reversed "r".  And starting there, it could never connect with any previous letter. (See the example "loyalty" above.)

Most all of the above is opinion, but there is only one real error that cries for correction, and you can see it in the word should SUd. The Wool character ought to occupy the same space  as "a" (a) not the space below the base line.

I look forward to the finished QS2.  (Also, you might use that Fontographer program to save the font in both PC and Mac Truetype formats.  You audience (me) will be most appreciative. )





  Has anyone seen the "QSJ Block" font I created? I would welcome a
detailed critique - or even a few observations.
   I used the trial period of a tool (Fontographer) to create it, and
will purchase it in a few months.

> Chuck
